# Instrumental Variables: How do they work?

Treatment variable $D$ is **.darkorange[endogenous]** (i.e. affected by a confounder $U$).
<br>
<br>
.center[
![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/maibennett/sta235/main/exampleSite/content/Classes/Week10/Highlights/images/iv1.png)
]

---
# Instrumental Variables: How do they work?

Instrumental variable $Z$ helps us separate $D$ into an **.darkorange[endogenous]** part (<i>D<sub>en</sub></i>, affected by confunder $U$) and an **.darkorange[exogenous]** part (<i>D<sub>ex</sub></i>, not affected by $U$).
<br>
<br>
.center[
![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/maibennett/sta235/main/exampleSite/content/Classes/Week10/Highlights/images/iv2.png)
]

---
# Instrumental Variables: Relevance condition

The **.darkorange[instrument]** needs to be **.darkorange[correlated]** with the **.darkorange[treatment]** (e.g. needs to "move" it)

.center[
![:scale 70%](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/maibennett/sta235/main/exampleSite/content/Classes/Week10/Highlights/images/iv3.png)
]

---
# Instrumental Variables: Exclusion condition

The **.darkorange[instrument]** can only affect the outcome **.darkorange[through the treatment]** (i.e. can't affect it directly or through another path).

.center[
![:scale 70%](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/maibennett/sta235/main/exampleSite/content/Classes/Week10/Highlights/images/iv4.png)
]


---
# Instrumental Variables: Exogeneity condition

The **.darkorange[instrument]** can't be affected by a **.darkorange[confounder]**.

.center[
![:scale 70%](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/maibennett/sta235/main/exampleSite/content/Classes/Week10/Highlights/images/iv5.png)
]

---

Highlights #2: Bias vs. Variance

---
# Bias vs. Variance

- In prediction, we want models with **.darkorange[low bias]** AND **.darkorange[low variance]**.

--

.box-2[Difficulty: Trade-off]

--

- **.darkorange[Variance:]** I train a model $f$ on a dataset $A$. How much will that model change if now I train it on dataset $B$?

  - If the model $f$ picks up on every singularity of dataset $A$, it will change a lot!

--

.box-4[More flexibility &#x2192; more variance]



---
# Bias vs. Variance

- In prediction, we want models with **.darkorange[low bias]** AND **.darkorange[low variance]**.



.box-2[Difficulty: Trade-off]

--

- **.darkorange[Bias:]** Error term we get from simplifying reality with a model.

  - If the model $f$ is too simple, bias will be large!

--

.box-4[Less flexibility &#x2192; more bias]

---

background-position: 50% 50%
class: left, bottom, inverse
.big[
Highlights #3: Validation sets
]

---
# Validation sets

.box-7[All accuracy measures need to be done on unseen data!]

--

- That's why we need to divide our data into **.darkorange[training]** (seen by the model) and **.darkorange[testing]** (unseen by the model) datasets.

--

- **.darkorange[Cross-validation]**: Iterative process where in each iteration we use a different part of the data for testing.

  - The **.darkorange[main advantage]** is that we will be using ALL the data for testing and training, and not be subject to the random variability of a specific partition.
